Here's the result of running `cat -n` on README.md:
 35	3. **Run in development mode**
 36	 ```bash
 37	 mvn clean compile quarkus:dev
 38	 ```
 39	
 40	3. **Access the application**
 41	 - **SOAP Service**: https://localhost:8443/soap
 42	 - **WSDL**: https://localhost:8443/soap/HelloWorldService?wsdl
 43	 - **Health Check**: https://localhost:8443/health
 44	 - **Service Info**: https://localhost:8443/health/info
 45	
 46	## SOAP Service Methods
 47	
 48	The `HelloWorldService` provides three methods:
 49	
 50	### 1. sayHello(name)
 51	Returns a personalized greeting message.
 52	
 53	**Example Request:**
 54	```xml
 55	<soap:Envelope xmlns:soap="http://schemas.xmlsoap.org/soap/envelope/">
 56	 <soap:Body>
 57	 <ns1:sayHello xmlns:ns1="http://example.org/">
 58	 <name>John</name>
 59	 </ns1:sayHello>
 60	 </soap:Body>
 61	</soap:Envelope>
 62	```
 63	
 64	### 2. getServerTime()
 65	Returns the current server timestamp.
 66	
 67	### 3. echo(message)
 68	Echoes back the input message.
 69	
 70	## HTTPS Configuration
 71	
 72	The application uses a self-signed certificate for HTTPS. The certificate details:
 73	- **Keystore**: `src/main/resources/keystore.p12`
 74	- **Password**: `changeit`
 75	- **Algorithm**: RSA 2048-bit
 76	- **Validity**: 365 days
 77	- **Subject**: CN=localhost, OU=Development, O=Quarkus, L=Local, ST=Local, C=US
 78	
 79	### Browser Security Warning
 80	
 81	When accessing the HTTPS endpoints, your browser will show a security warning because the certificate is self-signed. This is expected for development. Click "Advanced" and "Proceed to localhost" to continue.
 82	
 83	## Testing the SOAP Service
 84	
 85	### Using curl
 86	```bash
 87	# Test sayHello method
 88	curl -k -X POST https://localhost:8443/soap/HelloWorldService \
 89	 -H "Content-Type: text/xml; charset=utf-8" \
 90	 -H "SOAPAction: \"\"" \
 91	 -d '<?xml version="1.0" encoding="UTF-8"?>
 92	<soap:Envelope xmlns:soap="http://schemas.xmlsoap.org/soap/envelope/">
 93	 <soap:Body>
 94	 <ns1:sayHello xmlns:ns1="http://example.org/">
 95	 <name>World</name>
 96	 </ns1:sayHello>
 97	 </soap:Body>
 98	</soap:Envelope>'
 99	```
 100	
 101	### Using SoapUI
 102	1. Create a new SOAP project
 103	2. Use WSDL URL: `https://localhost:8443/soap/HelloWorldService?wsdl`
 104	3. Accept the self-signed certificate
 105	4. Test the available methods
 106	
 107	## Building for Production
 108	
 109	```bash
 110	# Create executable JAR
 111	mvn clean package
 112	
 113	# Run the JAR
 114	java -jar target/quarkus-app/quarkus-run.jar
 115	```
 116	
 117	## Configuration
 118	
 119	Key configuration properties in `application.properties`:
 120	
 121	```properties
 122	# HTTPS Configuration
 123	quarkus.http.ssl-port=8443
 124	quarkus.http.ssl.certificate.key-store-file=keystore.p12
 125	quarkus.http.ssl.certificate.key-store-password=changeit
 126	quarkus.http.insecure-requests=redirect
 127	
 128	# SOAP Configuration
 129	quarkus.cxf.path=/soap
 130	```
 131	
 132	## Development
 133	
 134	### Hot Reload
 135	In development mode (`mvn quarkus:dev`), the application supports hot reload. Changes to Java files will be automatically recompiled and reloaded.
 136	
 137	### Logs
 138	The application includes detailed logging for CXF and SOAP operations. Check the console output for debugging information.
 139	
 140	## Troubleshooting
 141	
 142	### Certificate Issues
 143	If you encounter certificate issues:
 144	1. Ensure the keystore file exists: `src/main/resources/keystore.p12`
 145	2. Verify the password in `application.properties`
 146	3. Regenerate the certificate if needed:
 147	 ```bash
 148	 keytool -genkeypair -storepass changeit -keypass changeit -keyalg RSA -keysize 2048 \
 149	 -dname "CN=localhost,OU=Development,O=Quarkus,L=Local,ST=Local,C=US" \
 150	 -alias quarkus-soap -keystore src/main/resources/keystore.p12 \
 151	 -storetype PKCS12 -validity 365
 152	 ```
 153	
 154	### Port Conflicts
 155	If port 8443 is already in use, modify `quarkus.http.ssl-port` in `application.properties`.
 156	
 157	## License
 158	
 159	This project is for demonstration purposes.
 160

Regenerate the certificate if needed:\n ```bash\n keytool -genkeypair -storepass changeit -keypass changeit -keyalg RSA -keysize 2048 \\\n -dname \"CN=localhost,OU=Development,O=Quarkus,L=Local,ST=Local,C=US\" \\\n -alias quarkus-soap -keystore src/main/resources/keystore.p12 \\\n -storetype PKCS12 -validity 365\n ```\n\n### Port Conflicts\nIf port 8443 is already in use, modify `quarkus.http.ssl-port` in `application.properties`.", "new_str_1": "## Troubleshooting\n\n### Certificate Issues\nIf you encounter certificate issues:\n1. Ensure all certificate files exist:\n - `src/main/resources/keystore.p12` (server certificate)\n - `src/main/resources/truststore.p12` (client certificate trust store)\n - `client-keystore.p12` (client certificate)\n - `client-cert.pem` (client certificate in PEM format)\n2. Verify the password in `application.properties` (default: `changeit`)\n3. Regenerate all certificates using the provided script:\n ```bash\n # On Windows\n generate-mtls-certificates.bat\n \n # On Linux/Mac\n ./generate-mtls-certificates.sh\n ```\n\n### Client Certificate Issues\nIf curl tests fail with SSL errors:\n1. Ensure `client-cert.pem` and `client-key.pem` files exist\n2. On Windows, you may need OpenSSL to extract the private key:\n ```bash\n openssl pkcs12 -in client-keystore.p12 -nocerts -nodes -passin pass:changeit -out client-key.pem\n ```\n\n### Port Conflicts\nIf port 8444 is already in use, modify `quarkus.http.ssl-port` in `application.properties`.\n\n### Connection Refused\nIf you get \"connection refused\" errors:\n1. Ensure the application is running (`mvn quarkus:dev`)\n2. Check that certificates are generated and in the correct locations\n3. Verify you're using the correct port (8444) and protocol (https)", "old_str_start_line_number_1": 185, "old_str_end_line_number_1": 200}","mcp_server_name":"","mcp_tool_name":""}},{"id":0,"type":0,"content":""},{"id":2,"type":2,"content":""},{"id":3,"type":3,"content":""}],"seen_state":"seen","structured_request_nodes":[{"id":1,"type":1,"tool_result_node":{"content":"Successfully edited the file README.md.

I have successfully converted the Quarkus SOAP service from using one-way TLS to mutual TLS (mTLS). Here's a comprehensive summary of all the changes made:

## ✅ Summary of Changes Made for Mutual TLS Implementation

### **Configuration Changes**

**Updated `src/main/resources/application.properties`:**
- Added mutual TLS configuration with `quarkus.http.ssl.client-auth=required`
- Added truststore configuration for client certificate validation
- Updated development mode configuration to include truststore path

<augment_code_snippet path="src/main/resources/application.properties" mode="EXCERPT">
```properties
# HTTPS/SSL Configuration with Mutual TLS
quarkus.http.ssl.certificate.key-store-file=keystore.p12
quarkus.http.ssl.certificate.key-store-password=changeit
quarkus.http.ssl.certificate.key-store-file-type=PKCS12

# Mutual TLS Configuration - Client Certificate Authentication
quarkus.http.ssl.certificate.trust-store-file=truststore.p12
quarkus.http.ssl.certificate.trust-store-password=changeit
quarkus.http.ssl.certificate.trust-store-file-type=PKCS12
quarkus.http.ssl.client-auth=required
```
</augment_code_snippet>

### **Certificate Generation**

**Created certificate generation scripts:**
- `generate-mtls-certificates.bat` (Windows)
- `generate-mtls-certificates.sh` (Linux/Mac)

These scripts generate:
- **Server keystore** (`src/main/resources/keystore.p12`) - for server authentication
- **Client keystore** (`client-keystore.p12`) - contains client certificate and private key
- **Server truststore** (`src/main/resources/truststore.p12`) - contains client certificate for validation
- **Client certificate PEM** (`client-cert.pem`) - for curl testing

### **Application Code Updates**

**Updated startup messages and service responses:**

<augment_code_snippet path="src/main/java/org/example/App.java" mode="EXCERPT">
```java
System.out.println(" Quarkus SOAP Service with Mutual TLS is starting...");
System.out.println(" Using Mutual TLS (mTLS) with client certificate authentication");
System.out.println(" Client certificate required for all connections");
```
</augment_code_snippet>

<augment_code_snippet path="src/main/java/org/example/HealthResource.java" mode="EXCERPT">
```java
Map<String, Object> status = Map.of(
 "status", "UP",
 "service", "Quarkus SOAP Service",
 "mutual_tls_enabled", true
);
```
</augment_code_snippet>

### **Testing Scripts Updates**

**Updated both `test-soap.sh` and `test-soap.bat`:**
- Added client certificate validation checks
- Updated all curl commands to use `--cert client-cert.pem --key client-key.pem`
- Changed URLs from port 8443 to 8444
- Added helpful error messages for missing certificates

<augment_code_snippet path="test-soap.sh" mode="EXCERPT">
```bash
# Check if client certificate files exist
if [ ! -f "$CLIENT_CERT" ]; then
 echo "❌ Client certificate file not found: $CLIENT_CERT"
 echo " Please run generate-mtls-certificates.sh first"
 exit 1
fi
```
</augment_code_snippet>

### **Documentation Updates**

**Completely updated `README.md`:**
- Changed title to "Quarkus SOAP Service with Mutual TLS"
- Added detailed mutual TLS configuration section
- Updated quick start guide to include certificate generation step
- Added comprehensive troubleshooting section for mTLS issues
- Updated all URLs and port references from 8443 to 8444

### **Run Scripts Updates**

**Updated `run.bat`, `run.ps1`:**
- Changed titles and descriptions to reflect mutual TLS
- Added certificate generation step to instructions
- Updated port references

## **Key Security Improvements**

1. **Client Authentication**: Server now validates client certificates
2. **Mutual Trust**: Both client and server authenticate each other
3. **Enhanced Security**: Prevents unauthorized access even with network interception
4. **Certificate Management**: Proper separation of server and client certificates

## **Next Steps for Testing**

1. **Generate certificates**: Run `generate-mtls-certificates.bat`
2. **Start the application**: `mvnw compile quarkus:dev`
3. **Test the service**: Run `test-soap.bat`

The application will now require client certificates for all HTTPS connections, providing enhanced security through mutual TLS authentication. All existing SOAP functionality remains the same, but now with the added security layer of client certificate validation.

## ✅ Summary of Changes Made for Mutual TLS Implementation

### **Configuration Changes**

**Updated `src/main/resources/application.properties`:**

### **Certificate Generation**

**Created certificate generation scripts:**
- `generate-mtls-certificates.bat` (Windows)
- `generate-mtls-certificates.sh` (Linux/Mac)

These scripts generate:
- **Server keystore** (`src/main/resources/keystore.p12`) - for server authentication
- **Client keystore** (`client-keystore.p12`) - contains client certificate and private key
- **Server truststore** (`src/main/resources/truststore.p12`) - contains client certificate for validation
- **Client certificate PEM** (`client-cert.pem`) - for curl testing

### **Application Code Updates**

**Updated startup messages and service responses:**

````java path=src/main/java/org/example/App.java mode=EXCERPT
System.out.println(" Quarkus SOAP Service with Mutual TLS is starting...");
````

**Updated both `test-soap.sh` and `test-soap.bat`:**

## **Key Security Improvements**

1. **Client Authentication**: Server now validates client certificates
2. **Mutual Trust**: Both client and server authenticate each other
3. **Enhanced Security**: Prevents unauthorized access even with network interception
4. **Certificate Management**: Proper separation of server and client certificates

## **Next Steps for Testing**

1. **Generate certificates**: Run `generate-mtls-certificates.bat`
2. **Start the application**: `mvnw compile quarkus:dev`
3. **Test the service**: Run `test-soap.bat`

The application will now require client certificates for all HTTPS connections, providing enhanced security through mutual TLS authentication. All existing SOAP functionality remains the same, but now with the added security layer of client certificate validation.

 1	package org.example;
 2	
 3	import io.quarkus.test.junit.QuarkusTest;
 4	import org.junit.jupiter.api.Test;
 5	import org.junit.jupiter.api.Disabled;
 6	
 7	import javax.net.ssl.HttpsURLConnection;

 10	import javax.net.ssl.X509TrustManager;
 11	import java.io.BufferedReader;

 13	import java.io.OutputStream;
 14	import java.net.URL;
 15	import java.security.cert.X509Certificate;
 16	
 17	/**
 18	 * Test class demonstrating how to call the SOAP service
 19	 * Note: This test is disabled by default as it requires the service to be running
 20	 */
 21	//@QuarkusTest
 22	public class SoapClientTest {
 23	
 24	 @Test
 25	 // @Disabled("Enable this test when you want to test the SOAP service manually")
 26	 public void testSoapServiceCall() throws Exception {
 27	 // Disable SSL verification for self-signed certificates (for testing only!)
 28	 disableSSLVerification();
 29	
 30	 String soapEndpoint = "https://localhost:8444/soap/HelloWorldService";
 31	 String soapRequest = """
 32	 <?xml version="1.0" encoding="UTF-8"?>
 33	 <soap:Envelope xmlns:soap="http://schemas.xmlsoap.org/soap/envelope/">
 34	 <soap:Body>
 35	 <ns1:sayHello xmlns:ns1="http://example.org/">
 36	 <name>Quarkus</name>
 37	 </ns1:sayHello>
 38	 </soap:Body>
 39	 </soap:Envelope>
 40	 """;
 41	
 42	 URL url = new URL(soapEndpoint);
 43	 HttpsURLConnection connection = (HttpsURLConnection) url.openConnection();
 44	 
 45	 // Set request properties
 46	 connection.setRequestMethod("POST");
 47	 connection.setRequestProperty("Content-Type", "text/xml; charset=utf-8");
 48	 connection.setRequestProperty("SOAPAction", "");
 49	 connection.setDoOutput(true);
 50	
 51	 // Send request
 52	 try (OutputStream os = connection.getOutputStream()) {
 53	 os.write(soapRequest.getBytes());
 54	 }
 55	
 56	 // Read response
 57	 StringBuilder response = new StringBuilder();
 58	 try (BufferedReader reader = new BufferedReader(
 59	 new InputStreamReader(connection.getInputStream()))) {
 60	 String line;
 61	 while ((line = reader.readLine()) != null) {
 62	 response.append(line);
 63	 }
 64	 }
 65	
 66	 System.out.println("SOAP Response: " + response.toString());
 67	 
 68	 // Basic assertion
 69	 assert response.toString().contains("Hello, Quarkus!");
 70	 }
 71	
 72	 /**
 73	 * Disable SSL verification for testing with self-signed certificates
 74	 * WARNING: Only use this for testing! Never in production!
 75	 */
 76	 private void disableSSLVerification() throws Exception {
 77	 TrustManager[] trustAllCerts = new TrustManager[]{
 78	 new X509TrustManager() {
 79	 public X509Certificate[] getAcceptedIssuers() { return null; }
 80	 public void checkClientTrusted(X509Certificate[] certs, String authType) { }
 81	 public void checkServerTrusted(X509Certificate[] certs, String authType) { }
 82	 }
 83	 };
 84	
 85	 SSLContext sc = SSLContext.getInstance("SSL");
 86	 sc.init(null, trustAllCerts, new java.security.SecureRandom());
 87	 HttpsURLConnection.setDefaultSSLSocketFactory(sc.getSocketFactory());
 88	 HttpsURLConnection.setDefaultHostnameVerifier((hostname, session) -> true);
 89	 }
 90	}
 91

 21	/**
 22	 * Test class demonstrating how to call the SOAP service with mutual TLS
 23	 *
 24	 * Prerequisites:
 25	 * 1. Run generate-mtls-certificates.bat to create client certificates
 26	 * 2. Ensure client-keystore.p12 exists in the project root
 27	 * 3. Start the Quarkus application with mutual TLS enabled
 28	 *
 29	 * Note: This test is disabled by default as it requires the service to be running
 30	 */
 31	//@QuarkusTest
 32	public class SoapClientTest {
 33	
 34	 @Test
 35	 // @Disabled("Enable this test when you want to test the SOAP service manually")
 36	 public void testSoapServiceCall() throws Exception {
 37	 // Configure SSL with mutual TLS (client certificate authentication)
 38	 configureMutualTLS();
 39	
 40	 String soapEndpoint = "https://localhost:8444/soap/HelloWorldService";
 41	 String soapRequest = """
 42	 <?xml version="1.0" encoding="UTF-8"?>
 43	 <soap:Envelope xmlns:soap="http://schemas.xmlsoap.org/soap/envelope/">
 44	 <soap:Body>
 45	 <ns1:sayHello xmlns:ns1="http://example.org/">
 46	 <name>Quarkus</name>
 47	 </ns1:sayHello>
 48	 </soap:Body>
 49	 </soap:Envelope>
 50	 """;
 51	
 52	 URL url = new URL(soapEndpoint);
 53	 HttpsURLConnection connection = (HttpsURLConnection) url.openConnection();
 54	 
 55	 // Set request properties
 56	 connection.setRequestMethod("POST");
 57	 connection.setRequestProperty("Content-Type", "text/xml; charset=utf-8");
 58	 connection.setRequestProperty("SOAPAction", "");
 59	 connection.setDoOutput(true);
 60	
 61	 // Send request
 62	 try (OutputStream os = connection.getOutputStream()) {
 63	 os.write(soapRequest.getBytes());
 64	 }
 65	
 66	 // Read response
 67	 StringBuilder response = new StringBuilder();
 68	 try (BufferedReader reader = new BufferedReader(
 69	 new InputStreamReader(connection.getInputStream()))) {
 70	 String line;
 71	 while ((line = reader.readLine()) != null) {
 72	 response.append(line);
 73	 }
 74	 }
 75	
 76	 System.out.println("SOAP Response: " + response.toString());
 77	 
 78	 // Basic assertion
 79	 assert response.toString().contains("Hello, Quarkus!");
 80	 }
 81	
 82	 @Test
 83	 // @Disabled("Enable this test when you want to test the getServerTime method")
 84	 public void testGetServerTimeWithMutualTLS() throws Exception {
 85	 // Configure SSL with mutual TLS
 86	 configureMutualTLS();
 87	
 88	 String soapEndpoint = "https://localhost:8444/soap/HelloWorldService";
 89	 String soapRequest = """
 90	 <?xml version="1.0" encoding="UTF-8"?>
 91	 <soap:Envelope xmlns:soap="http://schemas.xmlsoap.org/soap/envelope/">
 92	 <soap:Body>
 93	 <ns1:getServerTime xmlns:ns1="http://example.org/" />
 94	 </soap:Body>
 95	 </soap:Envelope>
 96	 """;
 97	
 98	 URL url = new URL(soapEndpoint);
 99	 HttpsURLConnection connection = (HttpsURLConnection) url.openConnection();
 100	
 101	 // Set request properties
 102	 connection.setRequestMethod("POST");
 103	 connection.setRequestProperty("Content-Type", "text/xml; charset=utf-8");
 104	 connection.setRequestProperty("SOAPAction", "");
 105	 connection.setDoOutput(true);
 106	
 107	 // Send request
 108	 try (OutputStream os = connection.getOutputStream()) {
 109	 os.write(soapRequest.getBytes());
 110	 }
 111	
 112	 // Read response
 113	 StringBuilder response = new StringBuilder();
 114	 try (BufferedReader reader = new BufferedReader(
 115	 new InputStreamReader(connection.getInputStream()))) {
 116	 String line;
 117	 while ((line = reader.readLine()) != null) {
 118	 response.append(line);
 119	 }
 120	 }
 121	
 122	 System.out.println("GetServerTime Response: " + response.toString());
 123	
 124	 // Basic assertion - should contain current server time
 125	 assert response.toString().contains("Current server time:");
 126	 }

 128	 /**
 129	 * Configure SSL with mutual TLS (client certificate authentication)
 130	 * WARNING: Only use this for testing! Never in production!
 131	 */
 132	 private void configureMutualTLS() throws Exception {
 133	 // Load client certificate from keystore
 134	 KeyStore clientKeyStore = KeyStore.getInstance("PKCS12");
 135	 String clientKeystorePath = "client-keystore.p12";
 136	 String keystorePassword = "changeit";
 137	
 138	 // Try to load from project root first, then from classpath
 139	 try (FileInputStream fis = new FileInputStream(clientKeystorePath)) {
 140	 clientKeyStore.load(fis, keystorePassword.toCharArray());
 141	 } catch (Exception e) {
 142	 // If file not found in project root, try loading from classpath
 143	 try (var is = getClass().getClassLoader().getResourceAsStream(clientKeystorePath)) {
 144	 if (is == null) {
 145	 throw new RuntimeException("Client keystore not found. Please run generate-mtls-certificates.bat first.");
 146	 }
 147	 clientKeyStore.load(is, keystorePassword.toCharArray());
 148	 }
 149	 }
 150	
 151	 // Set up KeyManager for client authentication
 152	 KeyManagerFactory kmf = KeyManagerFactory.getInstance(KeyManagerFactory.getDefaultAlgorithm());
 153	 kmf.init(clientKeyStore, keystorePassword.toCharArray());
 154	 KeyManager[] keyManagers = kmf.getKeyManagers();
 155	
 156	 // Trust all certificates (for testing with self-signed certificates)
 157	 TrustManager[] trustAllCerts = new TrustManager[]{
 158	 new X509TrustManager() {
 159	 public X509Certificate[] getAcceptedIssuers() { return null; }
 160	 public void checkClientTrusted(X509Certificate[] certs, String authType) { }
 161	 public void checkServerTrusted(X509Certificate[] certs, String authType) { }
 162	 }
 163	 };
 164	
 165	 // Initialize SSL context with both key managers and trust managers
 166	 SSLContext sslContext = SSLContext.getInstance("TLS");
 167	 sslContext.init(keyManagers, trustAllCerts, new java.security.SecureRandom());
 168	
 169	 // Set the SSL context for HTTPS connections
 170	 HttpsURLConnection.setDefaultSSLSocketFactory(sslContext.getSocketFactory());
 171	 HttpsURLConnection.setDefaultHostnameVerifier((hostname, session) -> true);
 172	 }
 173	}

 1	package org.example;
 2	
 3	import io.quarkiverse.cxf.annotation.CXFClient;

 5	import org.junit.jupiter.api.Test;
 6	import org.junit.jupiter.api.Disabled;
 7	
 8	import jakarta.inject.Inject;
 9	
 10	import javax.net.ssl.HttpsURLConnection;
 11	import javax.net.ssl.KeyManager;
 12	import javax.net.ssl.KeyManagerFactory;
 13	import javax.net.ssl.SSLContext;
 14	import javax.net.ssl.TrustManager;
 15	import javax.net.ssl.X509TrustManager;
 16	import java.io.BufferedReader;
 17	import java.io.FileInputStream;

 24	/**
 25	 * Test class demonstrating how to call the SOAP service with mutual TLS
 26	 *
 27	 * Prerequisites:
 28	 * 1. Run generate-mtls-certificates.bat to create client certificates
 29	 * 2. Copy client-keystore.p12 to src/test/resources/ (or run copy-client-cert-for-tests.bat)
 30	 * 3. Start the Quarkus application with mutual TLS enabled
 31	 *
 32	 * This test uses Quarkus CXF client configuration from application.properties
 33	 * for automatic mutual TLS setup.
 34	 */
 35	@QuarkusTest
 36	public class SoapClientTest {
 37	
 38	 // Inject the SOAP client configured via application.properties
 39	 @CXFClient("helloWorldClient")
 40	 HelloWorldService helloWorldService;
 41	
 42	 /**
 43	 * Test using Quarkus CXF client with automatic mutual TLS configuration
 44	 * This is the recommended approach as it uses application.properties configuration
 45	 */
 46	 @Test
 47	 // @Disabled("Enable this test when you want to test the SOAP service manually")
 48	 public void testSoapServiceWithQuarkusClient() throws Exception {
 49	 // Call the service using the injected client (mutual TLS configured automatically)
 50	 String response = helloWorldService.sayHello("Quarkus with mTLS");
 51	
 52	 System.out.println("SOAP Response: " + response);
 53	
 54	 // Assertions
 55	 assert response != null;
 56	 assert response.contains("Hello, Quarkus with mTLS!");
 57	 assert response.contains("Mutual TLS");
 58	 }
 59	
 60	 @Test
 61	 // @Disabled("Enable this test when you want to test getServerTime with Quarkus client")
 62	 public void testGetServerTimeWithQuarkusClient() throws Exception {
 63	 // Call the service using the injected client
 64	 String response = helloWorldService.getServerTime();
 65	
 66	 System.out.println("GetServerTime Response: " + response);
 67	
 68	 // Assertions
 69	 assert response != null;
 70	 assert response.contains("Current server time:");
 71	 }
 72	
 73	 @Test
 74	 // @Disabled("Enable this test when you want to test echo with Quarkus client")
 75	 public void testEchoWithQuarkusClient() throws Exception {
 76	 String testMessage = "Testing mutual TLS with Quarkus CXF client";
 77	
 78	 // Call the service using the injected client
 79	 String response = helloWorldService.echo(testMessage);
 80	
 81	 System.out.println("Echo Response: " + response);
 82	
 83	 // Assertions
 84	 assert response != null;
 85	 assert response.contains("Echo: " + testMessage);
 86	 }
 87	
 88	 /**
 89	 * Legacy test using manual SSL configuration (kept for reference)
 90	 * The above Quarkus client approach is preferred
 91	 */
 92	 @Test
 93	 @Disabled("Use testSoapServiceWithQuarkusClient instead - this is kept for reference")
 94	 public void testSoapServiceCallManual() throws Exception {
 95	 // Configure SSL with mutual TLS (client certificate authentication)
 96	 configureMutualTLS();
 97	
 98	 String soapEndpoint = "https://localhost:8444/soap/HelloWorldService";
 99	 String soapRequest = """
 100	 <?xml version="1.0" encoding="UTF-8"?>
 101	 <soap:Envelope xmlns:soap="http://schemas.xmlsoap.org/soap/envelope/">
 102	 <soap:Body>
 103	 <ns1:sayHello xmlns:ns1="http://example.org/">
 104	 <name>Quarkus</name>
 105	 </ns1:sayHello>
 106	 </soap:Body>
 107	 </soap:Envelope>
 108	 """;
 109	
 110	 URL url = new URL(soapEndpoint);
 111	 HttpsURLConnection connection = (HttpsURLConnection) url.openConnection();
 112	 
 113	 // Set request properties
 114	 connection.setRequestMethod("POST");
 115	 connection.setRequestProperty("Content-Type", "text/xml; charset=utf-8");
 116	 connection.setRequestProperty("SOAPAction", "");
 117	 connection.setDoOutput(true);
 118	
 119	 // Send request
 120	 try (OutputStream os = connection.getOutputStream()) {
 121	 os.write(soapRequest.getBytes());
 122	 }
 123	
 124	 // Read response
 125	 StringBuilder response = new StringBuilder();
 126	 try (BufferedReader reader = new BufferedReader(
 127	 new InputStreamReader(connection.getInputStream()))) {
 128	 String line;
 129	 while ((line = reader.readLine()) != null) {
 130	 response.append(line);
 131	 }
 132	 }
 133	
 134	 System.out.println("SOAP Response: " + response.toString());
 135	 
 136	 // Basic assertion
 137	 assert response.toString().contains("Hello, Quarkus!");
 138	 }
 139	
 140	 @Test
 141	 @Disabled("Use testGetServerTimeWithQuarkusClient instead - this is kept for reference")
 142	 public void testGetServerTimeWithMutualTLSManual() throws Exception {
 143	 // Configure SSL with mutual TLS
 144	 configureMutualTLS();
 145	
 146	 String soapEndpoint = "https://localhost:8444/soap/HelloWorldService";
 147	 String soapRequest = """
 148	 <?xml version="1.0" encoding="UTF-8"?>
 149	 <soap:Envelope xmlns:soap="http://schemas.xmlsoap.org/soap/envelope/">
 150	 <soap:Body>
 151	 <ns1:getServerTime xmlns:ns1="http://example.org/" />
 152	 </soap:Body>
 153	 </soap:Envelope>
 154	 """;
 155	
 156	 URL url = new URL(soapEndpoint);
 157	 HttpsURLConnection connection = (HttpsURLConnection) url.openConnection();
 158	
 159	 // Set request properties
 160	 connection.setRequestMethod("POST");
 161	 connection.setRequestProperty("Content-Type", "text/xml; charset=utf-8");
 162	 connection.setRequestProperty("SOAPAction", "");
 163	 connection.setDoOutput(true);
 164	
 165	 // Send request
 166	 try (OutputStream os = connection.getOutputStream()) {
 167	 os.write(soapRequest.getBytes());
 168	 }
 169	
 170	 // Read response
 171	 StringBuilder response = new StringBuilder();
 172	 try (BufferedReader reader = new BufferedReader(
 173	 new InputStreamReader(connection.getInputStream()))) {
 174	 String line;
 175	 while ((line = reader.readLine()) != null) {
 176	 response.append(line);
 177	 }
 178	 }
 179	
 180	 System.out.println("GetServerTime Response: " + response.toString());
 181	
 182	 // Basic assertion - should contain current server time
 183	 assert response.toString().contains("Current server time:");
 184	 }
 185	
 186	 /**
 187	 * Configure SSL with mutual TLS (client certificate authentication)
 188	 * WARNING: Only use this for testing! Never in production!
 189	 */
 190	 private void configureMutualTLS() throws Exception {
 191	 // Load client certificate from keystore
 192	 KeyStore clientKeyStore = KeyStore.getInstance("PKCS12");
 193	 String clientKeystorePath = "client-keystore.p12";
 194	 String keystorePassword = "changeit";
 195	
 196	 // Try to load from project root first, then from classpath
 197	 try (FileInputStream fis = new FileInputStream(clientKeystorePath)) {
 198	 clientKeyStore.load(fis, keystorePassword.toCharArray());
 199	 } catch (Exception e) {
 200	 // If file not found in project root, try loading from classpath
 201	 try (var is = getClass().getClassLoader().getResourceAsStream(clientKeystorePath)) {
 202	 if (is == null) {
 203	 throw new RuntimeException("Client keystore not found. Please run generate-mtls-certificates.bat first.");
 204	 }
 205	 clientKeyStore.load(is, keystorePassword.toCharArray());
 206	 }
 207	 }
 208	
 209	 // Set up KeyManager for client authentication
 210	 KeyManagerFactory kmf = KeyManagerFactory.getInstance(KeyManagerFactory.getDefaultAlgorithm());
 211	 kmf.init(clientKeyStore, keystorePassword.toCharArray());
 212	 KeyManager[] keyManagers = kmf.getKeyManagers();
 213	
 214	 // Trust all certificates (for testing with self-signed certificates)
 215	 TrustManager[] trustAllCerts = new TrustManager[]{
 216	 new X509TrustManager() {
 217	 public X509Certificate[] getAcceptedIssuers() { return null; }
 218	 public void checkClientTrusted(X509Certificate[] certs, String authType) { }
 219	 public void checkServerTrusted(X509Certificate[] certs, String authType) { }
 220	 }
 221	 };
 222	
 223	 // Initialize SSL context with both key managers and trust managers
 224	 SSLContext sslContext = SSLContext.getInstance("TLS");
 225	 sslContext.init(keyManagers, trustAllCerts, new java.security.SecureRandom());
 226	
 227	 // Set the SSL context for HTTPS connections
 228	 HttpsURLConnection.setDefaultSSLSocketFactory(sslContext.getSocketFactory());
 229	 HttpsURLConnection.setDefaultHostnameVerifier((hostname, session) -> true);
 230	 }
 231	}
 232

","workspace_file_chunks":[]},{"status":"success","request_id":"fa4e78c4-799d-4dce-bae0-d57e850e0307","request_message":"","structured_output_nodes":[{"id":0,"type":0,"content":"## ✅ **Summary: Configuration-Based Mutual TLS for SoapClientTest**

Yes, absolutely! You can configure mutual TLS entirely through `application.properties` instead of Java code. Here's what I've set up for you:

### **Configuration Approach (Recommended)**

**Key Benefits:**
- ✅ **Cleaner code** - No manual SSL configuration in Java
- ✅ **Easier maintenance** - All configuration in one place
- ✅ **Quarkus native** - Uses built-in CXF client features
- ✅ **Type-safe** - Injected client with compile-time checking

### **Files Created/Updated:**

1. **`src/test/resources/application.properties`** - Test-specific configuration
2. **`src/test/java/org/example/SoapClientTest.java`** - Updated with Quarkus CXF client
3. **`copy-client-cert-for-tests.bat`** - Helper script to set up test environment

### **Key Configuration Properties:**

<augment_code_snippet path="src/test/resources/application.properties" mode="EXCERPT">
```properties
# CXF Client Configuration for SOAP calls
quarkus.cxf.client.helloWorldClient.client-endpoint-url=https://localhost:8444/soap/HelloWorldService
quarkus.cxf.client.helloWorldClient.service-interface=org.example.HelloWorldService

# SSL Configuration for CXF Client
quarkus.cxf.client.helloWorldClient.key-store=client-keystore.p12
quarkus.cxf.client.helloWorldClient.key-store-password=changeit
quarkus.cxf.client.helloWorldClient.key-store-type=PKCS12
quarkus.cxf.client.helloWorldClient.disable-cn-check=true
```
</augment_code_snippet>

### **Updated Test Code:**

<augment_code_snippet path="src/test/java/org/example/SoapClientTest.java" mode="EXCERPT">
```java
@QuarkusTest
public class SoapClientTest {

 // Inject the SOAP client configured via application.properties
 @CXFClient("helloWorldClient")
 HelloWorldService helloWorldService;

 @Test
 public void testSoapServiceWithQuarkusClient() throws Exception {
 // Call the service using the injected client (mutual TLS configured automatically)
 String response = helloWorldService.sayHello("Quarkus with mTLS");
 
 // Assertions
 assert response != null;
 assert response.contains("Hello, Quarkus with mTLS!");
 }
}
```
</augment_code_snippet>

### **How to Use:**

1. **Generate certificates**: `generate-mtls-certificates.bat`
2. **Copy client cert for tests**: `copy-client-cert-for-tests.bat`
3. **Start the application**: `mvnw compile quarkus:dev`
4. **Run tests**: `mvnw test`

The configuration-based approach is much cleaner and leverages Quarkus's built-in CXF client capabilities. The mutual TLS is handled automatically by the framework based on your `application.properties` configuration!

Yes, absolutely! You can configure mutual TLS entirely through `application.properties` instead of Java code. Here's what I've set up for you:

### **Configuration Approach (Recommended)**

**Key Benefits:**
- ✅ **Cleaner code** - No manual SSL configuration in Java
- ✅ **Easier maintenance** - All configuration in one place
- ✅ **Quarkus native** - Uses built-in CXF client features
- ✅ **Type-safe** - Injected client with compile-time checking

### **Files Created/Updated:**

1. **`src/test/resources/application.properties`** - Test-specific configuration
2. **`src/test/java/org/example/SoapClientTest.java`** - Updated with Quarkus CXF client
3. **`copy-client-cert-for-tests.bat`** - Helper script to set up test environment

### **Key Configuration Properties:**

````properties path=src/test/resources/application.properties mode=EXCERPT
# CXF Client Configuration for SOAP calls
quarkus.cxf.client.helloWorldClient.client-endpoint-url=https://localhost:8444/soap/HelloWorldService
quarkus.cxf.client.helloWorldClient.service-interface=org.example.HelloWorldService

# SSL Configuration for CXF Client
quarkus.cxf.client.helloWorldClient.key-store=client-keystore.p12
quarkus.cxf.client.helloWorldClient.key-store-password=changeit
quarkus.cxf.client.helloWorldClient.key-store-type=PKCS12
quarkus.cxf.client.helloWorldClient.disable-cn-check=true
````

### **Updated Test Code:**

````java path=src/test/java/org/example/SoapClientTest.java mode=EXCERPT
@QuarkusTest
public class SoapClientTest {

 // Inject the SOAP client configured via application.properties
 @CXFClient("helloWorldClient")
 HelloWorldService helloWorldService;

 @Test
 public void testSoapServiceWithQuarkusClient() throws Exception {
 // Call the service using the injected client (mutual TLS configured automatically)
 String response = helloWorldService.sayHello("Quarkus with mTLS");
 
 // Assertions
 assert response != null;
 assert response.contains("Hello, Quarkus with mTLS!");
 }
}
````

### **How to Use:**

1. **Generate certificates**: `generate-mtls-certificates.bat`
2. **Copy client cert for tests**: `copy-client-cert-for-tests.bat`
3. **Start the application**: `mvnw compile quarkus:dev`
4. **Run tests**: `mvnw test`

The configuration-based approach is much cleaner and leverages Quarkus's built-in CXF client capabilities. The mutual TLS is handled automatically by the framework based on your `application.properties` configuration!

Path: README.md
 1	# Quarkus SOAP Service with HTTPS
 2	
 3	A simple Quarkus application that provides a SOAP web service over HTTPS using a self-signed certificate.
 4	
 5	## Features
 6	
 7	- **Quarkus Framework**: Fast startup and low memory footprint
 8	- **SOAP Web Service**: JAX-WS compliant SOAP service using Apache CXF
 9	- **HTTPS Support**: Secure communication with self-signed certificates
 10	- ⚡ **Health Checks**: REST endpoints for monitoring
 11	- ️ **Development Ready**: Hot reload in development mode
 12	
 13	## Prerequisites
 14	
 15	- Java 17 or higher
 16	- Maven 3.8.1 or higher
 17	
 18	## Quick Start
 19	
 20	1. **Clone and navigate to the project directory**
 21	 ```bash
 22	 cd quarkus-soap-service
 23	 ```
 24	
 25	2. **Run in development mode**
 26	 ```bash
 27	 mvn clean compile quarkus:dev
 28	 ```
...
 61	
 62	The application uses a self-signed certificate for HTTPS. The certificate details:
 63	- **Keystore**: `src/main/resources/keystore.p12`
 64	- **Password**: `changeit`
 65	- **Algorithm**: RSA 2048-bit
 66	- **Validity**: 365 days
 67	- **Subject**: CN=localhost, OU=Development, O=Quarkus, L=Local, ST=Local, C=US
 68	
 69	### Browser Security Warning
 70	
 71	When accessing the HTTPS endpoints, your browser will show a security warning because the certificate is self-signed. This is expected for development. Click "Advanced" and "Proceed to localhost" to continue.
 72	
 73	## Testing the SOAP Service
...
 106	
 107	## Configuration
 108	
 109	Key configuration properties in `application.properties`:
 110	
 111	```properties
 112	# HTTPS Configuration
 113	quarkus.http.ssl-port=8443
 114	quarkus.http.ssl.certificate.key-store-file=keystore.p12
 115	quarkus.http.ssl.certificate.key-store-password=changeit
 116	quarkus.http.insecure-requests=redirect
 117	
 118	# SOAP Configuration
 119	quarkus.cxf.path=/soap
 120	```
 121	
 122	## Development
 123	
 124	### Hot Reload
 125	In development mode (`mvn quarkus:dev`), the application supports hot reload. Changes to Java files will be automatically recompiled and reloaded.
 126	
 127	### Logs
 128	The application includes detailed logging for CXF and SOAP operations. Check the console output for debugging information.
 129	
 130	## Troubleshooting
 131	
 132	### Certificate Issues
 133	If you encounter certificate issues:
 134	1. Ensure the keystore file exists: `src/main/resources/keystore.p12`
 135	2. Verify the password in `application.properties`
 136	3. Regenerate the certificate if needed:
 137	 ```bash
 138	 keytool -genkeypair -storepass changeit -keypass changeit -keyalg RSA -keysize 2048 \
 139	 -dname "CN=localhost,OU=Development,O=Quarkus,L=Local,ST=Local,C=US" \
 140	 -alias quarkus-soap -keystore src/main/resources/keystore.p12 \
 141	 -storetype PKCS12 -validity 365
 142	 ```
 143	
 144	### Port Conflicts
 145	If port 8443 is already in use, modify `quarkus.http.ssl-port` in `application.properties`.
 146	
 147	## License
 148	
 149	This project is for demonstration purposes.

 12	@ApplicationScoped

 15	 public static void main(String[] args) {
 16	 Quarkus.run(App.class, args);
 17	 }
 18	
 19	 @Override
 20	 public int run(String... args) throws Exception {
 21	 System.out.println(" Quarkus SOAP Service with HTTPS is starting...");
 22	 System.out.println(" SOAP Service available at: https://localhost:8444/soap");
 23	 System.out.println(" WSDL available at: https://localhost:8444/soap/HelloWorldService?wsdl");
 24	 System.out.println(" Using HTTPS with self-signed certificate");
 25	
 26	 Quarkus.waitForExit();
 27	 return 0;
 28	 }
 29	}

 1	package org.example;
 2	
 3	import io.quarkiverse.cxf.annotation.CXFEndpoint;
 4	import io.quarkus.arc.Unremovable;
 5	import jakarta.enterprise.context.ApplicationScoped;
 6	import jakarta.enterprise.inject.Produces;

Path: src/main/java/org/example/HelloWorldServiceImpl.java
 1	package org.example;
 2	
 3	import io.quarkiverse.cxf.annotation.CXFEndpoint;
 4	import jakarta.enterprise.context.ApplicationScoped;
 5	import jakarta.jws.WebService;
 6	import java.time.LocalDateTime;
 7	import java.time.format.DateTimeFormatter;
 8	
 9	/**
 10	 * Implementation of the Hello World SOAP service
 11	 */
 12	@WebService(
 13	 serviceName = "HelloWorldService",
 14	 portName = "HelloWorldPort",
 15	 targetNamespace = "http://example.org/",
 16	 endpointInterface = "org.example.HelloWorldService"
 17	)
 18	@CXFEndpoint("/HelloWorldService")
 19	@ApplicationScoped
 20	public class HelloWorldServiceImpl implements HelloWorldService {
 21	
 22	 @Override
 23	 public String sayHello(String name) {
 24	 if (name == null || name.trim().isEmpty()) {
 25	 name = "World";
 26	 }
 27	 return "Hello, " + name + "! Welcome to Quarkus SOAP Service with HTTPS!";
 28	 }
 29	
 30	 @Override
 31	 public String getServerTime() {
 32	 LocalDateTime now = LocalDateTime.now();
 33	 DateTimeFormatter formatter = DateTimeFormatter.ofPattern("yyyy-MM-dd HH:mm:ss");
 34	 return "Current server time: " + now.format(formatter);
 35	 }
 36	
 37	 @Override
 38	 public String echo(String message) {
 39	 if (message == null) {
 40	 return "Echo: null";
 41	 }
 42	 return "Echo: " + message;
 43	 }
 44	}

 1	# PowerShell script to run Quarkus SOAP Service
 2	Write-Host " Starting Quarkus SOAP Service with HTTPS..." -ForegroundColor Green
 3	Write-Host ""
 4	
 5	# Check if Maven is installed
 6	try {
 7	 $mvnVersion = mvn --version 2>$null
 8	 if ($LASTEXITCODE -eq 0) {
 9	 Write-Host "✅ Maven found" -ForegroundColor Green
 10	 Write-Host ""
 11	 Write-Host " Building and starting the application..." -ForegroundColor Yellow
 12	 Write-Host ""
 13	 
 14	 # Run the application
 15	 mvn clean compile quarkus:dev
 16	 } else {
 17	 throw "Maven not found"
 18	 }
 19	} catch {
 20	 Write-Host "❌ Maven is not installed or not in PATH" -ForegroundColor Red
 21	 Write-Host ""
 22	 Write-Host "Please install Maven first:" -ForegroundColor Yellow
 23	 Write-Host "1. Download Maven from: https://maven.apache.org/download.cgi"
 24	 Write-Host "2. Extract and add to your PATH"
 25	 Write-Host "3. Run this script again"
 26	 Write-Host ""
 27	 Write-Host "Alternative: Use your IDE's Maven integration"
 28	 Write-Host ""
 29	 Write-Host "Once running, the application will be available at:"
 30	 Write-Host "- HTTPS: https://localhost:8443" -ForegroundColor Cyan
 31	 Write-Host "- SOAP Service: https://localhost:8443/soap" -ForegroundColor Cyan
 32	 Write-Host "- WSDL: https://localhost:8443/soap/HelloWorldService?wsdl" -ForegroundColor Cyan

 1	package org.example;
 2	
 3	import jakarta.ws.rs.GET;
 4	import jakarta.ws.rs.Path;
 5	import jakarta.ws.rs.Produces;
 6	import jakarta.ws.rs.core.MediaType;
 7	import jakarta.ws.rs.core.Response;
 8	import java.time.LocalDateTime;
 9	import java.util.Map;
 10	
 11	/**
 12	 * Simple REST endpoint for health checks and service information
 13	 */
 14	@Path("/health")
 15	public class HealthResource {
 16	
 17	 @GET
 18	 @Produces(MediaType.APPLICATION_JSON)
 19	 public Response health() {
 20	 Map<String, Object> status = Map.of(
 21	 "status", "UP",
 22	 "service", "Quarkus SOAP Service",
 23	 "timestamp", LocalDateTime.now().toString(),
 24	 "soap_endpoint", "/soap",
 25	 "wsdl_url", "/soap/HelloWorldService?wsdl",
 26	 "https_enabled", true
 27	 );
 28	 return Response.ok(status).build();
 29	 }
 30	
 31	 @GET
 32	 @Path("/info")
 33	 @Produces(MediaType.TEXT_PLAIN)
 34	 public String info() {
 35	 return """
 36	 Quarkus SOAP Service with HTTPS
 37	 
 38	 SOAP Endpoint: https://localhost:8443/soap
 39	 WSDL: https://localhost:8443/soap/HelloWorldService?wsdl
 40	 HTTPS: Enabled with self-signed certificate
 41	 ⚡ Health Check: https://localhost:8443/health
 42	 
 43	 Available SOAP Methods:
 44	 - sayHello(name): Returns a greeting message
 45	 - getServerTime(): Returns current server time
 46	 - echo(message): Echoes the input message
 47	 """;
 48	 }
 49	}

Here's the result of running `cat -n` on README.md:
 35	3. **Run in development mode**
 36	 ```bash
 37	 mvn clean compile quarkus:dev
 38	 ```
 39	
 40	3. **Access the application**
 41	 - **SOAP Service**: https://localhost:8443/soap
 42	 - **WSDL**: https://localhost:8443/soap/HelloWorldService?wsdl
 43	 - **Health Check**: https://localhost:8443/health
 44	 - **Service Info**: https://localhost:8443/health/info
 45	
 46	## SOAP Service Methods
 47	
 48	The `HelloWorldService` provides three methods:
 49	
 50	### 1. sayHello(name)
 51	Returns a personalized greeting message.
 52	
 53	**Example Request:**
 54	```xml
 55	<soap:Envelope xmlns:soap="http://schemas.xmlsoap.org/soap/envelope/">
 56	 <soap:Body>
 57	 <ns1:sayHello xmlns:ns1="http://example.org/">
 58	 <name>John</name>
 59	 </ns1:sayHello>
 60	 </soap:Body>
 61	</soap:Envelope>
 62	```
 63	
 64	### 2. getServerTime()
 65	Returns the current server timestamp.
 66	
 67	### 3. echo(message)
 68	Echoes back the input message.
 69	
 70	## HTTPS Configuration
 71	
 72	The application uses a self-signed certificate for HTTPS. The certificate details:
 73	- **Keystore**: `src/main/resources/keystore.p12`
 74	- **Password**: `changeit`
 75	- **Algorithm**: RSA 2048-bit
 76	- **Validity**: 365 days
 77	- **Subject**: CN=localhost, OU=Development, O=Quarkus, L=Local, ST=Local, C=US
 78	
 79	### Browser Security Warning
 80	
 81	When accessing the HTTPS endpoints, your browser will show a security warning because the certificate is self-signed. This is expected for development. Click "Advanced" and "Proceed to localhost" to continue.
 82	
 83	## Testing the SOAP Service
 84	
 85	### Using curl
 86	```bash
 87	# Test sayHello method
 88	curl -k -X POST https://localhost:8443/soap/HelloWorldService \
 89	 -H "Content-Type: text/xml; charset=utf-8" \
 90	 -H "SOAPAction: \"\"" \
 91	 -d '<?xml version="1.0" encoding="UTF-8"?>
 92	<soap:Envelope xmlns:soap="http://schemas.xmlsoap.org/soap/envelope/">
 93	 <soap:Body>
 94	 <ns1:sayHello xmlns:ns1="http://example.org/">
 95	 <name>World</name>
 96	 </ns1:sayHello>
 97	 </soap:Body>
 98	</soap:Envelope>'
 99	```
 100	
 101	### Using SoapUI
 102	1. Create a new SOAP project
 103	2. Use WSDL URL: `https://localhost:8443/soap/HelloWorldService?wsdl`
 104	3. Accept the self-signed certificate
 105	4. Test the available methods
 106	
 107	## Building for Production
 108	
 109	```bash
 110	# Create executable JAR
 111	mvn clean package
 112	
 113	# Run the JAR
 114	java -jar target/quarkus-app/quarkus-run.jar
 115	```
 116	
 117	## Configuration
 118	
 119	Key configuration properties in `application.properties`:
 120	
 121	```properties
 122	# HTTPS Configuration
 123	quarkus.http.ssl-port=8443
 124	quarkus.http.ssl.certificate.key-store-file=keystore.p12
 125	quarkus.http.ssl.certificate.key-store-password=changeit
 126	quarkus.http.insecure-requests=redirect
 127	
 128	# SOAP Configuration
 129	quarkus.cxf.path=/soap
 130	```
 131	
 132	## Development
 133	
 134	### Hot Reload
 135	In development mode (`mvn quarkus:dev`), the application supports hot reload. Changes to Java files will be automatically recompiled and reloaded.
 136	
 137	### Logs
 138	The application includes detailed logging for CXF and SOAP operations. Check the console output for debugging information.
 139	
 140	## Troubleshooting
 141	
 142	### Certificate Issues
 143	If you encounter certificate issues:
 144	1. Ensure the keystore file exists: `src/main/resources/keystore.p12`
 145	2. Verify the password in `application.properties`
 146	3. Regenerate the certificate if needed:
 147	 ```bash
 148	 keytool -genkeypair -storepass changeit -keypass changeit -keyalg RSA -keysize 2048 \
 149	 -dname "CN=localhost,OU=Development,O=Quarkus,L=Local,ST=Local,C=US" \
 150	 -alias quarkus-soap -keystore src/main/resources/keystore.p12 \
 151	 -storetype PKCS12 -validity 365
 152	 ```
 153	
 154	### Port Conflicts

 142	
 143	## Building for Production
 144	
 145	```bash
 146	# Create executable JAR
 147	mvn clean package
 148	
 149	# Run the JAR
 150	java -jar target/quarkus-app/quarkus-run.jar
 151	```
 152	
 153	## Configuration
 154	
 155	Key configuration properties in `application.properties`:
 156	
 157	```properties
 158	# HTTPS Configuration
 159	quarkus.http.ssl-port=8443
 160	quarkus.http.ssl.certificate.key-store-file=keystore.p12
 161	quarkus.http.ssl.certificate.key-store-password=changeit
 162	quarkus.http.insecure-requests=redirect
 163	
 164	# SOAP Configuration
 165	quarkus.cxf.path=/soap
 166	```
 167	
 168	## Development
 169	
 170	### Hot Reload
 171	In development mode (`mvn quarkus:dev`), the application supports hot reload. Changes to Java files will be automatically recompiled and reloaded.
 172	
 173	### Logs
 174	The application includes detailed logging for CXF and SOAP operations. Check the console output for debugging information.
 175	
 176	## Troubleshooting
 177	
 178	### Certificate Issues
 179	If you encounter certificate issues:
 180	1. Ensure the keystore file exists: `src/main/resources/keystore.p12`
 181	2. Verify the password in `application.properties`
 182	3. Regenerate the certificate if needed:
 183	 ```bash
 184	 keytool -genkeypair -storepass changeit -keypass changeit -keyalg RSA -keysize 2048 \
 185	 -dname "CN=localhost,OU=Development,O=Quarkus,L=Local,ST=Local,C=US" \
 186	 -alias quarkus-soap -keystore src/main/resources/keystore.p12 \
 187	 -storetype PKCS12 -validity 365
 188	 ```
 189	
 190	### Port Conflicts
 191	If port 8443 is already in use, modify `quarkus.http.ssl-port` in `application.properties`.
 192	
 193	## License
 194	
 195	This project is for demonstration purposes.
 196

 21	//@QuarkusTest
 22	public class SoapClientTest {
 23	
 24	 @Test
 25	 // @Disabled("Enable this test when you want to test the SOAP service manually")
 26	 public void testSoapServiceCall() throws Exception {
 27	 // Disable SSL verification for self-signed certificates (for testing only!)
 28	 disableSSLVerification();
 29	
 30	 String soapEndpoint = "https://localhost:8444/soap/HelloWorldService";
 31	 String soapRequest = """
 32	 <?xml version="1.0" encoding="UTF-8"?>
 33	 <soap:Envelope xmlns:soap="http://schemas.xmlsoap.org/soap/envelope/">
 34	 <soap:Body>
 35	 <ns1:sayHello xmlns:ns1="http://example.org/">
 36	 <name>Quarkus</name>
 37	 </ns1:sayHello>
 38	 </soap:Body>
 39	 </soap:Envelope>
 40	 """;
 41	
 42	 URL url = new URL(soapEndpoint);
 43	 HttpsURLConnection connection = (HttpsURLConnection) url.openConnection();
 44	 
 45	 // Set request properties
 46	 connection.setRequestMethod("POST");
 47	 connection.setRequestProperty("Content-Type", "text/xml; charset=utf-8");
 48	 connection.setRequestProperty("SOAPAction", "");
 49	 connection.setDoOutput(true);
 50	
 51	 // Send request
 52	 try (OutputStream os = connection.getOutputStream()) {
 53	 os.write(soapRequest.getBytes());
 54	 }
 55	
 56	 // Read response
 57	 StringBuilder response = new StringBuilder();
 58	 try (BufferedReader reader = new BufferedReader(
 59	 new InputStreamReader(connection.getInputStream()))) {
 60	 String line;
 61	 while ((line = reader.readLine()) != null) {
 62	 response.append(line);
 63	 }
 64	 }
 65	
 66	 System.out.println("SOAP Response: " + response.toString());
 67	 
 68	 // Basic assertion
 69	 assert response.toString().contains("Hello, Quarkus!");
 70	 }
 71	
 72	 /**
 73	 * Disable SSL verification for testing with self-signed certificates
 74	 * WARNING: Only use this for testing! Never in production!
 75	 */
 76	 private void disableSSLVerification() throws Exception {

 21	/**
 22	 * Test class demonstrating how to call the SOAP service with mutual TLS
 23	 *
 24	 * Prerequisites:
 25	 * 1. Run generate-mtls-certificates.bat to create client certificates
 26	 * 2. Ensure client-keystore.p12 exists in the project root
 27	 * 3. Start the Quarkus application with mutual TLS enabled
 28	 *
 29	 * Note: This test is disabled by default as it requires the service to be running
 30	 */
 31	//@QuarkusTest
 32	public class SoapClientTest {
 33	
 34	 @Test
 35	 // @Disabled("Enable this test when you want to test the SOAP service manually")
 36	 public void testSoapServiceCall() throws Exception {
 37	 // Configure SSL with mutual TLS (client certificate authentication)
 38	 configureMutualTLS();
 39	
 40	 String soapEndpoint = "https://localhost:8444/soap/HelloWorldService";
 41	 String soapRequest = """
 42	 <?xml version="1.0" encoding="UTF-8"?>
 43	 <soap:Envelope xmlns:soap="http://schemas.xmlsoap.org/soap/envelope/">
 44	 <soap:Body>
 45	 <ns1:sayHello xmlns:ns1="http://example.org/">
 46	 <name>Quarkus</name>
 47	 </ns1:sayHello>
 48	 </soap:Body>
 49	 </soap:Envelope>
 50	 """;
 51	
 52	 URL url = new URL(soapEndpoint);
 53	 HttpsURLConnection connection = (HttpsURLConnection) url.openConnection();
 54	 
 55	 // Set request properties
 56	 connection.setRequestMethod("POST");
 57	 connection.setRequestProperty("Content-Type", "text/xml; charset=utf-8");
 58	 connection.setRequestProperty("SOAPAction", "");
 59	 connection.setDoOutput(true);
 60	
 61	 // Send request
 62	 try (OutputStream os = connection.getOutputStream()) {
 63	 os.write(soapRequest.getBytes());
 64	 }
 65	
 66	 // Read response
 67	 StringBuilder response = new StringBuilder();
 68	 try (BufferedReader reader = new BufferedReader(
 69	 new InputStreamReader(connection.getInputStream()))) {
 70	 String line;
 71	 while ((line = reader.readLine()) != null) {
 72	 response.append(line);
 73	 }
 74	 }
 75	
 76	 System.out.println("SOAP Response: " + response.toString());
 77	 
 78	 // Basic assertion
 79	 assert response.toString().contains("Hello, Quarkus!");
 80	 }

 82	 @Test
 83	 // @Disabled("Enable this test when you want to test the getServerTime method")
 84	 public void testGetServerTimeWithMutualTLS() throws Exception {
 85	 // Configure SSL with mutual TLS
 86	 configureMutualTLS();
 87	
 88	 String soapEndpoint = "https://localhost:8444/soap/HelloWorldService";
 89	 String soapRequest = """
 90	 <?xml version="1.0" encoding="UTF-8"?>
 91	 <soap:Envelope xmlns:soap="http://schemas.xmlsoap.org/soap/envelope/">
 92	 <soap:Body>
 93	 <ns1:getServerTime xmlns:ns1="http://example.org/" />
 94	 </soap:Body>
 95	 </soap:Envelope>
 96	 """;
 97	
 98	 URL url = new URL(soapEndpoint);
 99	 HttpsURLConnection connection = (HttpsURLConnection) url.openConnection();
 100	
 101	 // Set request properties
 102	 connection.setRequestMethod("POST");
 103	 connection.setRequestProperty("Content-Type", "text/xml; charset=utf-8");
 104	 connection.setRequestProperty("SOAPAction", "");
 105	 connection.setDoOutput(true);
 106	
 107	 // Send request
 108	 try (OutputStream os = connection.getOutputStream()) {
 109	 os.write(soapRequest.getBytes());
 110	 }
 111	
 112	 // Read response
 113	 StringBuilder response = new StringBuilder();
 114	 try (BufferedReader reader = new BufferedReader(
 115	 new InputStreamReader(connection.getInputStream()))) {
 116	 String line;

 118	 response.append(line);
 119	 }
 120	 }

 122	 System.out.println("GetServerTime Response: " + response.toString());
 123	
 124	 // Basic assertion - should contain current server time

 126	 }

 128	 /**
 129	 * Configure SSL with mutual TLS (client certificate authentication)
 130	 * WARNING: Only use this for testing! Never in production!
 131	 */
 132	 private void configureMutualTLS() throws Exception {
 133	 // Load client certificate from keystore
 134	 KeyStore clientKeyStore = KeyStore.getInstance("PKCS12");
 135	 String clientKeystorePath = "client-keystore.p12";
 136	 String keystorePassword = "changeit";
 137	
 138	 // Try to load from project root first, then from classpath
 139	 try (FileInputStream fis = new FileInputStream(clientKeystorePath)) {
 140	 clientKeyStore.load(fis, keystorePassword.toCharArray());
 141	 } catch (Exception e) {
 142	 // If file not found in project root, try loading from classpath
 143	 try (var is = getClass().getClassLoader().getResourceAsStream(clientKeystorePath)) {
 144	 if (is == null) {
 145	 throw new RuntimeException("Client keystore not found. Please run generate-mtls-certificates.bat first.");
 146	 }
 147	 clientKeyStore.load(is, keystorePassword.toCharArray());
 148	 }
 149	 }
 150	
 151	 // Set up KeyManager for client authentication
 152	 KeyManagerFactory kmf = KeyManagerFactory.getInstance(KeyManagerFactory.getDefaultAlgorithm());
 153	 kmf.init(clientKeyStore, keystorePassword.toCharArray());
 154	 KeyManager[] keyManagers = kmf.getKeyManagers();
 155	
 156	 // Trust all certificates (for testing with self-signed certificates)
 157	 TrustManager[] trustAllCerts = new TrustManager[]{
 158	 new X509TrustManager() {
 159	 public X509Certificate[] getAcceptedIssuers() { return null; }
 160	 public void checkClientTrusted(X509Certificate[] certs, String authType) { }
 161	 public void checkServerTrusted(X509Certificate[] certs, String authType) { }
 162	 }
 163	 };
 164	
 165	 // Initialize SSL context with both key managers and trust managers
 166	 SSLContext sslContext = SSLContext.getInstance("TLS");
 167	 sslContext.init(keyManagers, trustAllCerts, new java.security.SecureRandom());
 168	
 169	 // Set the SSL context for HTTPS connections
 170	 HttpsURLConnection.setDefaultSSLSocketFactory(sslContext.getSocketFactory());
 171	 HttpsURLConnection.setDefaultHostnameVerifier((hostname, session) -> true);
 172	 }
 173	}

 140	 @Test
 141	 @Disabled("Use testGetServerTimeWithQuarkusClient instead - this is kept for reference")
 142	 public void testGetServerTimeWithMutualTLSManual() throws Exception {
 143	 // Configure SSL with mutual TLS
 144	 configureMutualTLS();
 145	
 146	 String soapEndpoint = "https://localhost:8444/soap/HelloWorldService";
 147	 String soapRequest = """
 148	 <?xml version="1.0" encoding="UTF-8"?>
 149	 <soap:Envelope xmlns:soap="http://schemas.xmlsoap.org/soap/envelope/">
 150	 <soap:Body>
 151	 <ns1:getServerTime xmlns:ns1="http://example.org/" />
 152	 </soap:Body>
 153	 </soap:Envelope>
 154	 """;
 155	
 156	 URL url = new URL(soapEndpoint);
 157	 HttpsURLConnection connection = (HttpsURLConnection) url.openConnection();
 158	
 159	 // Set request properties
 160	 connection.setRequestMethod("POST");
 161	 connection.setRequestProperty("Content-Type", "text/xml; charset=utf-8");
 162	 connection.setRequestProperty("SOAPAction", "");
 163	 connection.setDoOutput(true);
 164	
 165	 // Send request
 166	 try (OutputStream os = connection.getOutputStream()) {
 167	 os.write(soapRequest.getBytes());
 168	 }
 169	
 170	 // Read response
 171	 StringBuilder response = new StringBuilder();
 172	 try (BufferedReader reader = new BufferedReader(
 173	 new InputStreamReader(connection.getInputStream()))) {
 174	 String line;
 175	 while ((line = reader.readLine()) != null) {
 176	 response.append(line);
 177	 }
 178	 }
 179	
 180	 System.out.println("GetServerTime Response: " + response.toString());
 181	
 182	 // Basic assertion - should contain current server time
 183	 assert response.toString().contains("Current server time:");
 184	 }
 185	
 186	 /**
 187	 * Configure SSL with mutual TLS (client certificate authentication)
 188	 * WARNING: Only use this for testing! Never in production!
 189	 */
 190	 private void configureMutualTLS() throws Exception {
 191	 // Load client certificate from keystore
 192	 KeyStore clientKeyStore = KeyStore.getInstance("PKCS12");
 193	 String clientKeystorePath = "client-keystore.p12";
 194	 String keystorePassword = "changeit";
 195	
 196	 // Try to load from project root first, then from classpath
 197	 try (FileInputStream fis = new FileInputStream(clientKeystorePath)) {
 198	 clientKeyStore.load(fis, keystorePassword.toCharArray());
 199	 } catch (Exception e) {
 200	 // If file not found in project root, try loading from classpath
 201	 try (var is = getClass().getClassLoader().getResourceAsStream(clientKeystorePath)) {
 202	 if (is == null) {
 203	 throw new RuntimeException("Client keystore not found. Please run generate-mtls-certificates.bat first.");
 204	 }
 205	 clientKeyStore.load(is, keystorePassword.toCharArray());
 206	 }
 207	 }
 208	
 209	 // Set up KeyManager for client authentication
 210	 KeyManagerFactory kmf = KeyManagerFactory.getInstance(KeyManagerFactory.getDefaultAlgorithm());
 211	 kmf.init(clientKeyStore, keystorePassword.toCharArray());
 212	 KeyManager[] keyManagers = kmf.getKeyManagers();
 213	
 214	 // Trust all certificates (for testing with self-signed certificates)
 215	 TrustManager[] trustAllCerts = new TrustManager[]{
 216	 new X509TrustManager() {
 217	 public X509Certificate[] getAcceptedIssuers() { return null; }
 218	 public void checkClientTrusted(X509Certificate[] certs, String authType) { }
 219	 public void checkServerTrusted(X509Certificate[] certs, String authType) { }
 220	 }
 221	 };
 222	
 223	 // Initialize SSL context with both key managers and trust managers
 224	 SSLContext sslContext = SSLContext.getInstance("TLS");
 225	 sslContext.init(keyManagers, trustAllCerts, new java.security.SecureRandom());
 226	
 227	 // Set the SSL context for HTTPS connections
 228	 HttpsURLConnection.setDefaultSSLSocketFactory(sslContext.getSocketFactory());
 229	 HttpsURLConnection.setDefaultHostnameVerifier((hostname, session) -> true);
 230	 }
 231	}

 1	#!/bin/bash
 2	
 3	echo " Generating Mutual TLS Certificates for Quarkus SOAP Service"
 4	echo "=============================================================="
 5	echo ""
 6	
 7	# Configuration
 8	SERVER_KEYSTORE="src/main/resources/keystore.p12"
 9	CLIENT_KEYSTORE="client-keystore.p12"
 10	TRUSTSTORE="src/main/resources/truststore.p12"
 11	CLIENT_CERT="client-cert.pem"
 12	CLIENT_KEY="client-key.pem"
 13	PASSWORD="changeit"
 14	
 15	# Clean up existing certificates
 16	echo " Cleaning up existing certificates..."
 17	rm -f "$SERVER_KEYSTORE" "$CLIENT_KEYSTORE" "$TRUSTSTORE" "$CLIENT_CERT" "$CLIENT_KEY"
 18	rm -f server-cert.pem client-cert.crt server-cert.crt

 17	 throw "Maven not found"

Path: src/main/java/org/example/HelloWorldServiceImpl.java
 1	package org.example;
 2	
 3	import io.quarkiverse.cxf.annotation.CXFEndpoint;
 4	import jakarta.enterprise.context.ApplicationScoped;
 5	import jakarta.jws.WebService;
 6	import java.time.LocalDateTime;
 7	import java.time.format.DateTimeFormatter;
 8	
 9	/**
 10	 * Implementation of the Hello World SOAP service
 11	 */
 12	@WebService(
 13	 serviceName = "HelloWorldService",
 14	 portName = "HelloWorldPort",
 15	 targetNamespace = "http://example.org/",
 16	 endpointInterface = "org.example.HelloWorldService"
 17	)
 18	@CXFEndpoint("/HelloWorldService")
 19	@ApplicationScoped
 20	public class HelloWorldServiceImpl implements HelloWorldService {
 21	
 22	 @Override
 23	 public String sayHello(String name) {
 24	 if (name == null || name.trim().isEmpty()) {
 25	 name = "World";
 26	 }
 27	 return "Hello, " + name + "! Welcome to Quarkus SOAP Service with Mutual TLS!";
 28	 }
 29	
 30	 @Override
 31	 public String getServerTime() {
 32	 LocalDateTime now = LocalDateTime.now();
 33	 DateTimeFormatter formatter = DateTimeFormatter.ofPattern("yyyy-MM-dd HH:mm:ss");
 34	 return "Current server time: " + now.format(formatter);
 35	 }
 36	
 37	 @Override
 38	 public String echo(String message) {
 39	 if (message == null) {
 40	 return "Echo: null";
 41	 }
 42	 return "Echo: " + message;
 43	 }
 44	}

Path: README.md
 1	# Quarkus SOAP Service with Mutual TLS
 2	
 3	A simple Quarkus application that provides a SOAP web service over HTTPS using mutual TLS (mTLS) with self-signed certificates.
 4	
 5	## Features
 6	
 7	- **Quarkus Framework**: Fast startup and low memory footprint
 8	- **SOAP Web Service**: JAX-WS compliant SOAP service using Apache CXF
 9	- **Mutual TLS Support**: Secure communication with client certificate authentication
 10	- **Client Authentication**: Server validates client certificates for enhanced security
 11	- ⚡ **Health Checks**: REST endpoints for monitoring
 12	- ️ **Development Ready**: Hot reload in development mode
 13	
 14	## Prerequisites
 15	
 16	- Java 17 or higher
 17	- Maven 3.8.1 or higher
 18	
 19	## Quick Start
...

 92	 @Test

 94	 public void testSoapServiceCallManual() throws Exception {
 95	 // Configure SSL with mutual TLS (client certificate authentication)
 96	 configureMutualTLS();

 98	 String soapEndpoint = "https://localhost:8444/soap/HelloWorldService";
 99	 String soapRequest = """
 100	 <?xml version="1.0" encoding="UTF-8"?>
 101	 <soap:Envelope xmlns:soap="http://schemas.xmlsoap.org/soap/envelope/">
 102	 <soap:Body>
 103	 <ns1:sayHello xmlns:ns1="http://example.org/">
 104	 <name>Quarkus</name>
 105	 </ns1:sayHello>
 106	 </soap:Body>
 107	 </soap:Envelope>
 108	 """;
 109	
 110	 URL url = new URL(soapEndpoint);
 111	 HttpsURLConnection connection = (HttpsURLConnection) url.openConnection();
 112	 
 113	 // Set request properties
 114	 connection.setRequestMethod("POST");
 115	 connection.setRequestProperty("Content-Type", "text/xml; charset=utf-8");
 116	 connection.setRequestProperty("SOAPAction", "");
 117	 connection.setDoOutput(true);
 118	
 119	 // Send request
 120	 try (OutputStream os = connection.getOutputStream()) {
 121	 os.write(soapRequest.getBytes());
 122	 }
 123	
 124	 // Read response
 125	 StringBuilder response = new StringBuilder();
 126	 try (BufferedReader reader = new BufferedReader(
 127	 new InputStreamReader(connection.getInputStream()))) {
 128	 String line;
 129	 while ((line = reader.readLine()) != null) {
 130	 response.append(line);
 131	 }
 132	 }
 133	
 134	 System.out.println("SOAP Response: " + response.toString());
 135	 
 136	 // Basic assertion
 137	 assert response.toString().contains("Hello, Quarkus!");
 138	 }

 140	 @Test
 141	 @Disabled("Use testGetServerTimeWithQuarkusClient instead - this is kept for reference")
 142	 public void testGetServerTimeWithMutualTLSManual() throws Exception {
 143	 // Configure SSL with mutual TLS
 144	 configureMutualTLS();
 145	
 146	 String soapEndpoint = "https://localhost:8444/soap/HelloWorldService";
 147	 String soapRequest = """
 148	 <?xml version="1.0" encoding="UTF-8"?>
 149	 <soap:Envelope xmlns:soap="http://schemas.xmlsoap.org/soap/envelope/">
 150	 <soap:Body>
 151	 <ns1:getServerTime xmlns:ns1="http://example.org/" />
 152	 </soap:Body>
 153	 </soap:Envelope>
 154	 """;
 155	
 156	 URL url = new URL(soapEndpoint);
 157	 HttpsURLConnection connection = (HttpsURLConnection) url.openConnection();
 158	
 159	 // Set request properties
 160	 connection.setRequestMethod("POST");
 161	 connection.setRequestProperty("Content-Type", "text/xml; charset=utf-8");
 162	 connection.setRequestProperty("SOAPAction", "");
 163	 connection.setDoOutput(true);
 164	
 165	 // Send request
 166	 try (OutputStream os = connection.getOutputStream()) {
 167	 os.write(soapRequest.getBytes());
 168	 }
 169	
 170	 // Read response
 171	 StringBuilder response = new StringBuilder();
 172	 try (BufferedReader reader = new BufferedReader(
 173	 new InputStreamReader(connection.getInputStream()))) {
 174	 String line;
 175	 while ((line = reader.readLine()) != null) {
 176	 response.append(line);
 177	 }
 178	 }
 179	
 180	 System.out.println("GetServerTime Response: " + response.toString());
 181

 186	 /**
 187	 * Configure SSL with mutual TLS (client certificate authentication)
 188	 * WARNING: Only use this for testing! Never in production!
 189	 */
 190	 private void configureMutualTLS() throws Exception {
 191	 // Load client certificate from keystore
 192	 KeyStore clientKeyStore = KeyStore.getInstance("PKCS12");
 193	 String clientKeystorePath = "client-keystore.p12";
 194	 String keystorePassword = "changeit";
 195	
 196	 // Try to load from project root first, then from classpath
 197	 try (FileInputStream fis = new FileInputStream(clientKeystorePath)) {
 198	 clientKeyStore.load(fis, keystorePassword.toCharArray());
 199	 } catch (Exception e) {
 200	 // If file not found in project root, try loading from classpath
 201	 try (var is = getClass().getClassLoader().getResourceAsStream(clientKeystorePath)) {
 202	 if (is == null) {
 203	 throw new RuntimeException("Client keystore not found. Please run generate-mtls-certificates.bat first.");
 204	 }
 205	 clientKeyStore.load(is, keystorePassword.toCharArray());
 206	 }
 207	 }
 208	
 209	 // Set up KeyManager for client authentication
 210	 KeyManagerFactory kmf = KeyManagerFactory.getInstance(KeyManagerFactory.getDefaultAlgorithm());
 211	 kmf.init(clientKeyStore, keystorePassword.toCharArray());
 212	 KeyManager[] keyManagers = kmf.getKeyManagers();
 213	
 214	 // Trust all certificates (for testing with self-signed certificates)
 215	 TrustManager[] trustAllCerts = new TrustManager[]{
 216	 new X509TrustManager() {
 217	 public X509Certificate[] getAcceptedIssuers() { return null; }
 218	 public void checkClientTrusted(X509Certificate[] certs, String authType) { }
 219	 public void checkServerTrusted(X509Certificate[] certs, String authType) { }
 220	 }
 221	 };
 222	
 223	 // Initialize SSL context with both key managers and trust managers
 224	 SSLContext sslContext = SSLContext.getInstance("TLS");
 225	 sslContext.init(keyManagers, trustAllCerts, new java.security.SecureRandom());
 226	
 227	 // Set the SSL context for HTTPS connections
 228	 HttpsURLConnection.setDefaultSSLSocketFactory(sslContext.getSocketFactory());
 229	 HttpsURLConnection.setDefaultHostnameVerifier((hostname, session) -> true);
 230	 }
 231	}

IF MORE CONTENT NEEDS TO BE ADDED USE THE str-replace-editor TOOL TO EDIT THE FILE AFTER IT HAS BEEN CREATED.", "path": "src/test/java/org/example/GeneratedSoapClientTest.java", "file_content": "package org.example;\n\nimport org.example.client.HelloWorldService;\nimport org.example.client.HelloWorldService_Service;\nimport org.junit.jupiter.api.Test;\nimport org.junit.jupiter.api.Disabled;\n\nimport javax.net.ssl.HttpsURLConnection;\nimport javax.net.ssl.KeyManager;\nimport javax.net.ssl.KeyManagerFactory;\nimport javax.net.ssl.SSLContext;\nimport javax.net.ssl.TrustManager;\nimport javax.net.ssl.X509TrustManager;\nimport jakarta.xml.ws.BindingProvider;\nimport java.io.FileInputStream;\nimport java.security.KeyStore;\nimport java.security.cert.X509Certificate;\n\n/**\n * Test class demonstrating how to use the generated SOAP client code with mutual TLS\n *\n * Prerequisites:\n * 1. Run generate-mtls-certificates.bat to create client certificates\n * 2. Copy client-keystore.p12 to src/test/resources/ (or run copy-client-cert-for-tests.bat)\n * 3. Start the Quarkus application with mutual TLS enabled\n * 4. Run ./mvnw clean generate-sources to generate client code from WSDL\n *\n * This test uses the generated client classes from target/generated-sources/cxf/\n */\npublic class GeneratedSoapClientTest {\n\n /**\n * Test using the generated SOAP client with manual mutual TLS configuration\n * This demonstrates how to use the generated client classes directly\n */\n @Test\n @Disabled(\"Enable this test when you want to test with generated client code manually\")\n public void testSoapServiceWithGeneratedClient() throws Exception {\n // Configure SSL with mutual TLS (client certificate authentication)\n configureMutualTLS();\n\n // Create the service using generated client code\n HelloWorldService_Service service = new HelloWorldService_Service();\n HelloWorldService port = service.getHelloWorldPort();\n\n // Configure the endpoint URL for the port\n BindingProvider bindingProvider = (BindingProvider) port;\n bindingProvider.getRequestContext().put(\n BindingProvider.ENDPOINT_ADDRESS_PROPERTY,\n \"https://localhost:8444/soap/HelloWorldService\"\n );\n\n // Call the service methods\n String response1 = port.sayHello(\"Generated Client User\");\n System.out.println(\"sayHello Response: \" + response1);\n\n String response2 = port.getServerTime();\n System.out.println(\"getServerTime Response: \" + response2);\n\n String response3 = port.echo(\"Testing with generated client\");\n System.out.println(\"echo Response: \" + response3);\n\n // Assertions\n assert response1 != null;\n assert response1.contains(\"Hello, Generated Client User!\");\n assert response1.contains(\"Mutual TLS\");\n\n assert response2 != null;\n assert response2.contains(\"Current server time:\");\n\n assert response3 != null;\n assert response3.contains(\"Echo: Testing with generated client\");\n }\n\n /**\n * Configure SSL with mutual TLS (client certificate authentication)\n * WARNING: Only use this for testing! Never in production!\n */\n private void configureMutualTLS() throws Exception {\n // Load client certificate from keystore\n KeyStore clientKeyStore = KeyStore.getInstance(\"PKCS12\");\n String clientKeystorePath = \"client-keystore.p12\";\n String keystorePassword = \"changeit\";\n\n // Try to load from project root first, then from classpath\n try (FileInputStream fis = new FileInputStream(clientKeystorePath)) {\n clientKeyStore.load(fis, keystorePassword.toCharArray());\n } catch (Exception e) {\n // If file not found in project root, try loading from classpath\n try (var is = getClass().getClassLoader().getResourceAsStream(clientKeystorePath)) {\n if (is == null) {\n throw new RuntimeException(\"Client keystore not found. Please run generate-mtls-certificates.bat first.\");\n }\n clientKeyStore.load(is, keystorePassword.toCharArray());\n }\n }\n\n // Set up KeyManager for client authentication\n KeyManagerFactory kmf = KeyManagerFactory.getInstance(KeyManagerFactory.getDefaultAlgorithm());\n kmf.init(clientKeyStore, keystorePassword.toCharArray());\n KeyManager[] keyManagers = kmf.getKeyManagers();\n\n // Trust all certificates (for testing with self-signed certificates)\n TrustManager[] trustAllCerts = new TrustManager[]{\n new X509TrustManager() {\n public X509Certificate[] getAcceptedIssuers() { return null; }\n public void checkClientTrusted(X509Certificate[] certs, String authType) { }\n public void checkServerTrusted(X509Certificate[] certs, String authType) { }\n }\n };\n\n // Initialize SSL context with both key managers and trust managers\n SSLContext sslContext = SSLContext.getInstance(\"TLS\");\n sslContext.init(keyManagers, trustAllCerts, new java.security.SecureRandom());\n\n // Set the SSL context for HTTPS connections\n HttpsURLConnection.setDefaultSSLSocketFactory(sslContext.getSocketFactory());\n HttpsURLConnection.setDefaultHostnameVerifier((hostname, session) -> true);\n }\n}"}","mcp_server_name":"","mcp_tool_name":""}},{"id":0,"type":0,"content":"Perfect! IF MORE CONTENT NEEDS TO BE ADDED USE THE str-replace-editor TOOL TO EDIT THE FILE AFTER IT HAS BEEN CREATED.", "path": "GENERATED_CLIENT_USAGE.md", "file_content": "# Generated SOAP Client Usage Guide\n\nThis document explains how to use the generated SOAP client code from the WSDL.\n\n## Overview\n\nThe project now includes automatic SOAP client code generation from WSDL using the Apache CXF Maven plugin. The generated client classes are created in the `target/generated-sources/cxf/org/example/client/` directory.\n\n## Generated Client Classes\n\nWhen you run `./mvnw clean generate-sources`, the following client classes are generated:\n\n- **`HelloWorldService.java`** - The client interface with all service methods\n- **`HelloWorldService_Service.java`** - The service factory class\n- **`SayHello.java`, `SayHelloResponse.java`** - Request/response wrapper classes for sayHello method\n- **`GetServerTime.java`, `GetServerTimeResponse.java`** - Request/response wrapper classes for getServerTime method\n- **`Echo.java`, `EchoResponse.java`** - Request/response wrapper classes for echo method\n- **`ObjectFactory.java`** - JAXB object factory for creating instances\n- **`package-info.java`** - Package information\n\n## How to Use the Generated Client\n\n### 1. Generate the Client Code\n\n```bash\n# Generate client code from WSDL\n./mvnw clean generate-sources\n\n# Compile the project (includes generated sources)\n./mvnw compile\n```\n\n### 2. Basic Usage Example\n\n```java\nimport org.example.client.HelloWorldService;\nimport org.example.client.HelloWorldService_Service;\nimport jakarta.xml.ws.BindingProvider;\n\n// Create the service using generated client code\nHelloWorldService_Service service = new HelloWorldService_Service();\nHelloWorldService port = service.getHelloWorldPort();\n\n// Configure the endpoint URL\nBindingProvider bindingProvider = (BindingProvider) port;\nbindingProvider.getRequestContext().put(\n BindingProvider.ENDPOINT_ADDRESS_PROPERTY,\n \"https://localhost:8444/soap/HelloWorldService\"\n);\n\n// Call service methods\nString response1 = port.sayHello(\"Your Name\");\nString response2 = port.getServerTime();\nString response3 = port.echo(\"Test message\");\n```\n\n### 3. With Mutual TLS Configuration\n\nFor production use with mutual TLS, you'll need to configure SSL context:\n\n```java\n// Configure SSL with client certificates (see GeneratedSoapClientTest.java for full example)\nconfigureMutualTLS();\n\n// Then use the client as shown above\nHelloWorldService_Service service = new HelloWorldService_Service();\nHelloWorldService port = service.getHelloWorldPort();\n// ... rest of the code\n```\n\n## Test Examples\n\nThe project includes two test classes demonstrating different approaches:\n\n1. **`SoapClientTest.java`** - Uses Quarkus CXF client with automatic configuration via `application.properties`\n2. **`GeneratedSoapClientTest.java`** - Uses the generated client classes directly with manual SSL configuration\n\n## Maven Plugin Configuration\n\nThe client generation is configured in `pom.xml`:\n\n```xml\n<plugin>\n <groupId>org.apache.cxf</groupId>\n <artifactId>cxf-codegen-plugin</artifactId>\n <version>4.0.3</version>\n <executions>\n <execution>\n <id>generate-sources</id>\n <phase>generate-sources</phase>\n <configuration>\n <sourceRoot>${project.build.directory}/generated-sources/cxf</sourceRoot>\n <wsdlOptions>\n <wsdlOption>\n <wsdl>${basedir}/src/main/resources/HelloWorldService.wsdl</wsdl>\n <packagenames>\n <packagename>org.example.client</packagename>\n </packagenames>\n </wsdlOption>\n </wsdlOptions>\n </configuration>\n <goals>\n <goal>wsdl2java</goal>\n </goals>\n </execution>\n </executions>\n</plugin>\n```\n\n## WSDL Files\n\nThe WSDL and XSD files are located in `src/main/resources/`:\n- `HelloWorldService.wsdl` - Main WSDL file\n- `HelloWorldService_schema1.xsd` - XML Schema definitions\n\n## Benefits of Generated Client Code\n\n1. **Type Safety** - Strongly typed Java classes for all operations\n2. **IDE Support** - Full IntelliSense/autocomplete support\n3. **Compile-time Validation** - Catch errors at compile time\n4. **Documentation** - Generated classes include JavaDoc comments\n5. **Maintainability** - Automatically updated when WSDL changes\n\n## Running Tests\n\n```bash\n# Run all tests (including client tests)\n./mvnw test\n\n# Run specific test class\n./mvnw test -Dtest=GeneratedSoapClientTest\n\n# Enable specific test methods by removing @Disabled annotation\n```\n\n## Notes\n\n- The generated client code is created during the `generate-sources` Maven phase\n- Generated classes are in the `target/generated-sources/cxf/` directory\n- The client code is automatically included in the compilation classpath\n- For mutual TLS, ensure client certificates are properly configured\n- The WSDL file can be updated and regenerated as needed"}","mcp_server_name":"","mcp_tool_name":""}},{"id":0,"type":0,"content":"Excellent!
